posts.name: Korcan
posts.cooked: For the next season, we are planning to switch to swerve drive modules. It will be our first time using swerve drives, and there are many different options available. We are wondering which module performs best overall — Mk4, Mk5, X2T, Thriftybot…

posts.name: M
posts.cooked: You’re not going to get a straightforward answer about that from anyone since all modules are essentially similar, differing only in price points, weight, features, and the sizes of their respective communities. Pick what suits your needs, what you can afford, and when you like. I'll be selecting the TTB abbreviation for Thrifty Bot due to WCP's ongoing Backorders on their FIRST in Michigan bundle and SDS not offering a competitive edge in either price or weight compared to our requirements.

posts.name: Isaac Proctor
posts.cooked: The ngl MK5n appears to look quite nice.

posts.name: Totally out of touch
posts.cooked: No team running MK5n has lost champs.

This is a religious question. You're going to get a lot of answers as we have a lot of cooler solutions right now.  

I would consider the following factors when choosing a solution, as they impact the total cost of ownership:  

- **CTRE software**: This tool eliminates headaches by simplifying code generation and configuration. A thrifty bot solution may also offer similar features.  
- **Support**: Joining teams or groups nearby can provide troubleshooting assistance. Additionally, understanding the company's reach and access to spare parts is important.  
- **Consumables**: Evaluate whether the drive consumes tires and is compatible with 3D-printed tires. Options like Colsons could be available.  
- **Parts costs**: Consider whether additional components such as a wheel encoder add expense. Exploring the possibility of using a smaller motor or standard 10-32 screws might reduce costs.  
- **Reliability**: Frequent repairs or retuning could increase maintenance time over the long term.  

There are many variables to weigh beyond just the sticker price.

MK5n looks pretty good.

The fully sealed unit along with the smaller footprint made us order a set to replace our mk4i's. Those modules have been bulletproof, so I trust S&G to release a quality product right from the start. The sealed unit is huge, no worry about carpet fuzz in the bevel gear or needing to ensure coverage to keep things out of the rest of the gears. Quick gear ratio changes are a nice plus too

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: My views are mine and mine alone

posts.cooked: Last thought. Buy an extra module or two and some spare parts. Have two modules on hand for easy replacement. Ensure you have both left and right drives available. All of these considerations should be factored into your total cost analysis.

Plummer Industries likely offers the best overall product. However, it’s not inexpensive, and the associated software isn’t easy to use either. You’d have to utilize the YAGSL Yet Another Generic Swerve Library or create a custom solution. The support and “Oh crap, this broke, but I CAN fix it before our next match” aspects are unmatched in quality, and the price accurately reflects that level of excellence.

I genuinely appreciate them and would prefer more teams to use them, although  $500 modules remain expensive and impractical for most organizations.

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked: Plummer Industries probably makes the best one overall. Maintainability might not be their strong suit though; their documentation is lacking, and the CAD model isn't accessible without purchase, complicating testing integration. Their parts are made from 6061 aluminum, which has led to issues in the past, notably impacting the use of SDS (Swerve Drive Specialties) components which use 7075 instead. Additionally, unlike other modules, Plummer Industries doesn’t provide extra mounting holes for cameras. But I can fix that before our next match. What else sets them apart?

posts.name: Mete Karadeniz
posts.cooked: Most teams use mk4i for their swerve modules, and I recommend using mk4i. There are many references for this module, but I also heard that X2T is very reliable at speed. I prefer mk4i to X2T especially for the first year.

For example, the entire wheel comes off with 1 or 2 bolts. The gears are easy to take off, and the entire module shouldn't take too long to work either. I would defer to [@Austin_Plummer](/u/austin_plummer); we had a pretty good chat about them at worlds and everything made sense afterwards. I will let them restate it here if they choose.

A 2.5-inch drive wheel will be problematic if there are obstacles on the field. Just because we haven’t encountered a cable bump since 2023 doesn’t mean it won’t happen in the future. I understand that with a 4-inch wheel, having a suspension tire fitted around it isn’t an issue, even if it’s 3D printed.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: My views are mine and mine alone

posts.name: Austin Plummer
posts.cooked:
There will be a significant amount of new documentation released shortly, providing further details on the features I've been able to explain more effectively in person and at events such as Worlds. While my ability to produce clear documentation is limited, this project focuses on improving that aspect. I prefer not to disrupt ongoing discussions by covering all the new information, but recent updates include support for the 3D-printed wheel mentioned earlier, with maintainability and modularity being key design objectives. However, there are drawbacks to these design choices as well.  

A major advantage of the current market offerings is the wide variety of options available, allowing teams to select features that best suit their specific needs and priorities. Since teams have diverse design priorities, there isn’t necessarily a single swerve module that works perfectly for every situation.

The text is:  
The Plummer bumper mounts are excellent, and their product stands out. @nstrike endorses them highly. We face a lot of intense competition in drive systems, which is truly remarkable.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: LPryor also highly recommends @nstrike, particularly noting his expertise in YAGSL, which he refers to as Yet Another Generic Swerve Library. LPryor believes @nstrike is a leading expert in swerve software.
